Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Development of Novel Two-photon Fluorescence Polymer Probes for High Resolution Deep Tissue Intravital Imaging

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
1403525/1403535
Kevin D. Belfield, University of Central Florida
Komatsu, Masanobu, Sanford-Burnham Medical Research Institute
Development of Novel Two-photon Fluorescence Polymer Probes for High Resolution Deep Tissue Intravital Imaging

Significance
Biophotonic materials and processes are fast becoming pervasive in many new and emerging technologies from telecommunications to biomedical imaging, technologies that have far reaching impact on society. In vivo imaging, coupled with efficient multifunctional nanoprobes, promises to transformationally impact the field of nanomedicine and diagnostics in a manner that may have profound effects on societal well being. Two-photon fluorescence microscopy (2PFM) for deep tissue imaging is a developing technology with unique subcellular resolution. To take full advantage of 2PFM, fluorescence probes with high two-photon absorption (2PA) cross-sections and high fluorescence quantum yields are critical all the while being nontoxic and heavy metal-free. The future of nanomedicine and diagnostics lies in the development of multifunctional nanoplatforms that combine both highly specific targeting and efficient imaging functionality, facilitating temporal and spatial site-specific imaging, not in carefully controlled cell culture but in vivo in living tissue. This highly interdisciplinary proposal aims to develop advanced polymer-based probes for in vivo 2PFM angiogenesis imaging. In vivo 2PFM may provide real-time, minimally invasive monitoring of tumor progression, a tumor?s response to anti-cancer therapies, and wound healing in much greater detail than is currently known. This project constitutes an excellent platform for interdisciplinary research training and education in advanced materials and microscopy techniques. Students that are traditionally underrepresented in science and engineering will be especially encouraged to participate in this project. There will be strong international engagement through Belfield?s participation in the European Commission?s FP7 Marie Curie Actions program, supporting the development of an interdisciplinary-trained, diverse, globally adept, highly skilled workforce.

Technical Description
Few efforts have been reported on approaches to push the limits and improve the contrast and quality of two-photon fluorescence microscopy (2PFM) imaging in tissue. In this proposal, we propose to dramatically improve probe performance and targeting selectivity in 2PFM imaging through controlled multivalency, integrating multiple highly efficient 2PA, near-IR emitting fluorophores and vectors that target specific biomarkers in a polymeric nanoplatform. This approach is expected to enhance cellular interaction through increased avidity and bioavailability due to the small size and biocompatibility of the nanoprobe. We propose a polymeric nanoplatform approach to prepare well-defined probes that provide high local fluorophore concentration to achieve high contrast imaging and multiple targeting moieties on the same polymer chain to enhance avidity, hence reducing the dose needed. This is expected to provide optical sectioning with subcellular resolution from deeper within tissue and make it possible to track biologically important events, such as sprouting of vessel tip cells, in three dimensions. Tumor angiogenesis is a complex biological process that can only be studied in living animals. However, techniques for the study of tumor angiogenesis in vivo are acutely lacking. We will push the limits of in vivo 2PFM by studying angiogenesis and vascular cell growth and movement, processes important for the pathogenesis of a number of diseases, while helping us gain a better understanding of the biology of tumor angiogenesis.

POR.DRECONTENT:
In this collaborative research project, Dr. Kevin Belfield and my group have set out to develop functional probes for in vivo two-photon fluorescence microscopy imaging for minimally invasive monitoring of malignant tumor tissues.

Two-photon fluorescence microscopy (2PFM) is a highly advanced microscopy technology that enables deep tissue imaging of living tissues. It can be used for monitoring tumor progression, blood vessel growth, and tumor’s response to anti-cancer therapies. This technology requires highly sophisticated fluorescence nanoparticle probes. The objective of this study was to develop fluorescent probes uniquely tailored for the highest 2PFM imaging capability to visualize tumor interior in much greater detail than what current technologies can offer. In particular, polymer nanoparticle probes with near-infrared wavelength window are suitable for the deep tissue imaging. We synthesized such fluorescence nanoparticle probes and tested them in cell culture as well as in tumor-bearing mice. The new probes enabled the visualization of tumor tissue interior without histological sample preparation, thus allowing real-time observations. The new probes were further improved for their photophysical properties for the better probe performance. Furthermore, we functionalized these probes in order to give target selectivity to the tumors. This was accomplished by the conjugation of vascular homing peptides that target specific biomarkers in a polymeric nonoplatform. We also developed unique mouse models to examine the utility of the new probes and the feasibility of live imaging of the tumor interior.

Our probe synthesis approach was designed to enhance cellular interaction through increased avidity and bioavailability due to the small size and biocompatibility of the nanoprobe. As a result, the new probes enhanced the quality of in vivo microscopy. This technology was developed for noninvasive analyses of tissue interior by fluorescence optical imaging. Therefore, we expect that the new probes and the synthesis methods will contribute to broad applications ranging from noninvasive cancer detection/monitoring in medical field to real-time in vivo analyses in broad biological sciences including physiology, cell biology, immunology, angiogenesis, tumor biology, and neuroscience. As it is said, “seeing is believing”. Our technology will provide high resolution images of biological events “in action” with 2-D and 3-D video. These images will be tremendously informative and will make it easy to understand for students and general public to learn various fields of biological sciences. For instance, this technology may enable us to see cancer cells invading surrounding tissues or penetrating into the blood circulation moving through blood vessel wall. We could watch new blood vessel formation and maturation processes and interaction with tumor cells and other stromal cells in action in tumor microenvironment. Impressive images in biology will certainly inspire and attract more students to the field. Images of various biological processes can also enhance public understanding and raise awareness in the importance of the biological sciences. For instance, real-time 3-D video images of malignant tumors could be broadcasted in education programs in TV and internet for general audience to enjoy learning how cancer malignancy progresses or how medical treatment could affect the disease. People can witness this using the advanced optical imaging technology. These images can be strong communication tools for advocating funding increase by the federal and local governments and other fund raising activities.
